_comment: Pre-defined material synergy pairs for sustainability briefing. Each synergy explains how two materials complement each other architecturally and environmentally.

synergies.explanation: Mass timber structure with timber linings creates a cohesive biogenic carbon strategy, sequestering CO2 while reducing reliance on concrete and steel.
Combining CLT structure with natural wool insulation maximises biogenic carbon storage and creates excellent hygroscopic moisture management.
Timber floor cassettes with cellulose insulation pairs structural carbon sequestration with recycled newspaper-based insulation for a low-embodied-carbon floor build-up.
Exposed concrete thermal mass paired with timber slat ceiling balances passive heating/cooling with visual warmth and partial carbon offsetting.
Using recycled steel for both primary and secondary structure maximises circular economy benefits when high recycled content (85%+) is specified throughout.
Rammed earth walls with lime plaster create a breathable, low-carbon envelope that improves with age through carbonation.
Natural stone combined with low-carbon concrete sub-base addresses sustainability while providing durable, low-maintenance surfaces.
High-performance glazing with timber soffit optimises daylighting while the timber provides visual warmth and carbon storage to offset glazing impact.
Traditional brick aesthetics with natural wool insulation provide excellent thermal performance and breathability with reduced synthetic materials.
Cork flooring's natural thermal properties complement timber wall panels, creating an interior palette of renewable, carbon-storing materials.
Linoleum flooring with timber wall panels creates an interior palette of natural, renewable materials with low VOC emissions.
Glulam primary structure with timber roof framing creates an all-timber structural system, maximising carbon sequestration and enabling prefabrication.
CLT floors with glulam beams create an all-timber structural system, maximising carbon sequestration and enabling prefabrication.
Clay plaster walls with timber floor structure combine moisture-regulating finishes with carbon-storing structure for healthy indoor environments.
Recycled aggregate terrazzo on low-carbon concrete base reduces concrete's embodied carbon while diverting waste from landfill.
Acoustic baffles on exposed CLT ceiling provide sound control while maintaining the visual impact and carbon benefits of mass timber.
Bamboo flooring with cork wall panels combines two rapidly renewable materials with excellent acoustic and thermal properties.
Wool felt acoustic panels with timber slat ceiling create biophilic interiors using natural materials with complementary acoustic properties.
Mycelium tiles with bio-fibre panels combine two carbon-negative materials grown from agricultural waste for pioneering low-carbon interiors.
Reclaimed timber throughout extends carbon storage indefinitely while eliminating new material impacts and celebrating material history.
